awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Optimal Provision of Backhaul and Radio Access Networks: A Cross-Network Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
The explosive growth in the number of smart consumer devices leads to projections that within 10 years' time, wireless cellular networks need to offer 1000x throughput increase over the current 4G technology. By that time the network should be able to deliver fiber-like user experience boasting 10 Gb/s individual transmission rate for data intensive cloud-based applications. To move such a huge amount of data from the network to the users' handheld devices in real time, revolutionary network infrastructure and advanced network provision are required. Two key enablers of the envisioned future mobile networks are the ultra-dense deployment of base stations and centralized cloud-based processing. This project addresses the challenging problem of managing such densely deployed, cloud-based radio access networks.

The proposed research includes the introduction of a unified cross-network framework to manage a cloud-based radio access network. Important aspects of resource management in different sub-networks, including the backhaul and the cloud networks, will be considered. The project focuses on providing theoretical insights as well as designing practical algorithms for the optimal provisioning of a cloud-based radio access network. Fundamental computational issues of key cross-network resource management tasks will be investigated, revealing their intrinsic complexity. Moreover, practical schemes capable of optimally utilizing resources across networks will be developed, using cross-network optimization formulations. These algorithms will be optimized to fully exploit the computational resources offered by the cloud centers, addressing key issues such as parallel/distributed implementation, asynchronous computation, and load balancing. The goal is to determine how computational resources should be deployed through the proposed cross-network framework to dramatically improve the performance of a cloud-based radio access network.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report ? NSF Award# 1813090

 

Project Title: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Optimal Provision of Backhaul and Radio Access Networks: A Cross-Network Approach

Recipient Organization: University of Minnesota

Project/Grant Period: 09/28/2017 ? 08/31/2020

PI: Mingyi Hong

 

 

The proposed research focuses on providing theoretical insights and designing practical algorithms for the optimal provisioning of a cloud-based Radio Access Network (RAN) ? a network architecture that has been envisioned to play a key role in the next-generation wireless systems. The focus of this work is to design practical schemes capable of optimally utilizing resources across different kinds of networks (such as the backhaul, and the access networks), using our developed optimization formulations. The developed algorithms will be able to fully exploit the computational resources offered by the cloud centers, and to address practical issues such as parallel/distributed implementation, asynchronous computation, and load balancing.

First, the project has developed a number of efficient algorithms that allow the network designers to efficiently perform resource management tasks over a few special deployment scenarios of RAN. For example, it has developed a massively parallelizable algorithm for cloud-RAN systems, with the so-called zone-based topologies where each zone consists of a large number of network nodes, and is controlled by a cloud center. The developed algorithm is decentralized, which enables the cloud centers to coordinate themselves to obtain high throughput. The algorithm is also highly efficient, because it runs an order of magnitude faster compared with existing centralized algorithms. Moreover, it is also flexible to incorporate a number of physical layer transmission schemes, such as multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) transmission, full duplex relay schemes, among others.

Moreover, this project also considered a number of specific cross-layer wireless network application scenarios, and developed application-specific algorithms. We list below two types of important applications it has considered.

  • The project has considered optimizing a Service-Oriented network, which supports multiple on-demand services over fixed communication networks. Each service can be requested by the network nodes consists of a prespecified sequence of functions, called a service function chain (SFC), while each service function in an SFC can only be provided by some specific network nodes. An effective network provisioning algorithm has been developed, which optimally directs different flows so they go through the required services sequentially, while satisfying link and node capacity constraints.
  • The project has developed network provisioning algorithms for the problem of video streaming over a multi-user interfering wireless network. Specifically, it developed a novel strategy, which combines the application layer reinforcement learning scheme (to allocate streaming rates) with the physical layer resource optimization schemes (to optimize the individual user's physically achievable rate), so that the users? long-term fair quality of experience (QoE) can be maximized.  The developed strategy represents a significant departure from the existing schemes, which ignores the interplay between physical layer dynamics and application layer requirements. 

 

Overall, the proposed research has been strongly motivated by the need for optimally managing and provision the envisioned cloud-based RAN. The project proposed state-of-the-art algorithms that push the state-of-the-art performance in many application scenarios. The results of this project have been summarized in a number of publications in journals including IEEE Journal on Selected Areas of Communication and IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing.

Modified by: Mingyi Hong
